level.name: Level 1 - Orders
level.title: Orders - explanations
level.content:
Before digging further to the limbos of the Schynder's theorem, one must first see some notions in order to understand it clearly.

The first one is the order.

An order is a notion which enable us to compare elements of a set with each others. One define it as following:

An order is a binary relation which is reflexive, antisymmetric and transitive. Let \(E\) be a set. An internal relation \( \leq \) on \( E \) is called an order relation if for all elements \( x, y, z \in E \), we have :

  • \( x \leq x \), which is the reflexivity. An element is related, comparable to itself.
  • \( (x \leq y \wedge y \leq x) \Rightarrow x = y \), which is the antisymmetry. Two different elements cannot be related in two different directions, otherwise they must be equal.
  • \( (x \leq y \wedge y \leq z) \Rightarrow x \leq z \), which is the transitivity. If an element is related to a second one and that second element is alo related with a third one, then the first and the third elements are related each other.

question.title: Let \(E = \{ 0, 2, 1, 5, (2, 1) \} \). Has this set a relation of order ?
question.answer: Well, there is an order but only for some elements.
